an4.21:4.2: At one time the Buddha was staying near Sāvatthī, in Jeta’s Grove, Anāthapiṇḍika’s monastery.
an4.21:4.3: There the Buddha addressed the mendicants:
an4.21:5.1: “Mendicants, this one time, when I was first awakened, I was staying near Uruvelā at the goatherd’s banyan tree on the bank of the Nerañjarā River.
an4.21:5.2: As I was in private solitude this thought came to mind:
an4.21:5.3: ‘It’s unpleasant to live without respect and reverence.
an4.21:5.4: What ascetic or brahmin should I honor and respect and rely on?’
an4.21:6.2: ‘I’d honor and respect and rely on another ascetic or brahmin so as to complete the full spectrum of ethics, if it was incomplete.
an4.21:6.3: But I don’t see any other ascetic or brahmin in this world—with its gods, Māras, and Brahmās, this population with its ascetics and brahmins, its gods and humans—who is more accomplished than myself in ethics, who I should honor and respect and rely on.
an4.21:7.1: ‘I’d honor and respect and rely on another ascetic or brahmin so as to complete the full spectrum of samādhi, if it was incomplete.
an4.21:7.2: But I don’t see any other ascetic or brahmin … who is more accomplished than myself in samādhi …
an4.21:8.1: ‘I’d honor and respect and rely on another ascetic or brahmin so as to complete the full spectrum of wisdom, if it was incomplete.
an4.21:8.2: But I don’t see any other ascetic or brahmin in this world … who is more accomplished than myself in wisdom …
an4.21:9.1: ‘I’d honor and respect and rely on another ascetic or brahmin so as to complete the full spectrum of freedom, if it was incomplete.
an4.21:9.2: But I don’t see any other ascetic or brahmin in this world … who is more accomplished than myself in freedom …’
an4.21:10.2: ‘Why don’t I honor and respect and rely on the same Dharma to which I was awakened?’
an4.21:11.1: And then Brahmā Sahampati, knowing what I was thinking,
an4.21:11.2: vanished from the Brahmā realm and appeared in front of me, as easily as a strong man would extend or contract his arm.
an4.21:11.5: He arranged his robe over one shoulder, knelt on his right knee, raised his cupped palms toward the Buddha, and said:
an4.21:11.6: ‘That’s so true, Blessed One! That’s so true, Holy One!
an4.21:11.7: All the perfect ones, the fully awakened Buddhas who lived in the past honored and respected and relied on this same Dharma.
an4.21:11.8: All the perfect ones, the fully awakened Buddhas who will live in the future will honor and respect and rely on this same Dharma.
an4.21:11.9: May the Blessed One, who is the perfect one, the fully awakened Buddha at present, also honor and respect and rely on this same Dharma.’
an4.21:11.11: Then he went on to say:
an4.21:12.4: destroyer of the sorrows of many—
an4.21:13.2: they did live, they do live,
an4.21:13.4: This is the nature of the Buddhas.
an4.21:15.2: Then he bowed and respectfully circled me, keeping me on his right side, before vanishing right there.
an4.21:15.3: Then—knowing the request of Brahmā and what was suitable for myself—I honored and respected and lived supported by the same Dharma to which I was awakened.
an4.21:15.4: And since the Saṅgha has also achieved greatness, I also respect the Saṅgha.”
